text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm with mahi-mahi ceviche that's right
the fish so nice they named it twice in
a classic while fairly classic South
American presentation called ceviche
which is basically a cold uncooked fish
salad and I'll explain the uncooked part
later but here we go
alright so I told my fish guy I need 3/4
of a pound of mahi-mahi trimmed no bone
no skin so I'm gonna take my mahi-mahi
and I'm gonna cut it into strips and
then in two sort of cubes so I'm gonna
cut the strip in half and then I'm just
gonna cube it into I don't know what is
that like 3/8 of an inch
something like that you don't want it
any larger than that but it could be
smaller than that so the smaller it is
the faster it will marinate but I kind
of like a larger piece to bite into so
I'm gonna do it that way I'm also gonna
take some jalapeno
and give it a really really fine mince
no seeds of course I'm gonna add my
jalapeno to my fish I'm also gonna add a
pinch of dry oregano which I've crushed
between my fingertips a big pinch of
salt a nice shot of cayenne and then
what makes all this possible citrus
juice I'm using half lemon half lime
alright some people use two-thirds lime
one-third lemon doesn't matter you need
about 2/3 of a cup altogether and I'm
gonna pour that citrus juice over the
fish give it a really good mix it all
needs to be touching the marinade
okay so Pat it down with your spoon if a
bunch of fish is still up on top of the
surface squeeze another lemon and/or
lime in there but mine is just about
perfect I'm gonna cover that with
plastic I'm gonna make sure it's
touching the fish don't just wrap the
bowl push it down
that's gonna help keep the fish in the
citrus juice alright we're gonna throw
that in the fridge and we're gonna let
that sit for a minimum of one hour two
hours I think is perfect I would say 6
to 8 hours as the max I don't like it
like overnight I think it gets over
ceviche and what I like to do after
about a half-hour I'm gonna give it a
little toss with the spoon just to make
sure the stuff at the bottom comes up to
the top and I get a nice even cooking
quote-unquote and what's basically
happening here is the acid in the lemon
and lime juice is
cooking the fish and it's not really
cooking it it's actually doing something
called denaturing and what denaturing is
of course is taking something that's
natured in making it less natured
actually I'm not sure what that means
all right but anyway we can google that
later okay so while our fish is cooking
in that lemon and lime juice in the
fridge I'm gonna prep the rest of my
garnishes which are English cucumber I
took a piece I peeled it I cut it in
half lengthwise scooped out the seeds
and then cut it into strips what I'm
trying to do is create little cubes
about the same size as the fish which is
what I did there you go
I'm also gonna take some radishes a
couple radishes I put them on my
Japanese mandolin a vegetable slicer
which gives me these nice little cool
little julienne cuts very nice I'm also
gonna take one orange and make orange
Supremes you remember when we did that
video good times all right so we're
gonna take our orange Supremes and this
time we're gonna cut them down that's
right into little pieces about the same
size as the fish and the cucumber see
what we're doing here last but not least
I'm gonna take a half an avocado take
the pit out use a spoon to scoop it out
to remove it from the skin there's that
the peel is it peeler skin and then yes
guess what shape we're gonna cut it into
that's right small cubes all right the
fish is done
meaning it's sat in that acid bath for
about two hours and it looks cooked and
basically it is cooked I mean sorry
denatured to that I'm gonna add my
cucumber I'm gonna add my radish I'm
going to add my orange some fresh
chopped cilantro and some blurry chives
and by the way you got to read the blog
post why I'm using chive and not the
traditional raw onion so that will make
for some fascinating reading and then
I'm gonna give it a nice splash of olive
oil not some really strong peppery
extra-virgin something light and
possibly fruity all right so I'm gonna
drizzle in some olive oil I'm gonna give
this a toss and we're ready that's it
how amazingly simple as that now one big
tip here please taste and adjust for
salts
if it's under salted it's just not going
to have that kick and of course you
don't to over salt
so taste taste taste and adjust and
there you go
mahi-mahi ceviche so delicious fresh
lively vibrant flavors just a winner
all-around winner perfect for summer you
don't have to use the stove there's no
heat involved and yes it's true the fish
cooks quote-unquote in that acid so this
is totally fine to eat
you're not eating raw fish technically
oh and of course I should announce this
is not a classic version because I did
put extra things like fruit and cucumber
and stuff in it so people from Peru
they're not happy right now they're
writing me letters and emails and
comments as we speak but that's okay
Peruvian law has no jurisdiction in San
